articles.headline: Despite Gain in Jobs Data, Wall Street Is Skeptical
articles.snippet: The economy added 166,000 jobs in October, the fastest pace in five months, but investors seem to think the outlook for the fourth quarter remains cloudy.
articles.abstract: The economy added 166,000 jobs in October, the fastest pace in five months, but investors seem to think the outlook for the fourth quarter remains cloudy.
articles.lead_paragraph: A robust employment report offered investors a pleasant surprise yesterday, but some thought it was too good to be true.

articles.headline: With Resolution Unlikely, Writers Guild Sets Strike for Monday
articles.snippet: Hollywood’s movie and television writers plan to embark on an industrywide strike for the first time since 1988.
articles.abstract: Hollywood’s movie and television writers plan to embark on an industrywide strike for the first time since 1988.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 —When the sun rises here on Monday morning, movie and television writers will be ready to head for their assigned picket lines outside Hollywood’s studios and production sites.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: As Japan Ages, Prisons Adapt to Going Gray
articles.snippet: With one of the world’s most rapidly aging societies, Japan is confronting a sharp increase in older prisoners.
articles.abstract: With one of the world’s most rapidly aging societies, Japan is confronting a sharp increase in older prisoners.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONOMICHI, Japan — In the prison’s brightly lighted workroom here, 47 inmates sat behind long tables and quietly performed their chores.

articles.headline: The Dings and Dents of Toyota
articles.snippet: Toyota has had a run of bad news this year as concerns linger that management has not kept up with a rapid growth rate.
articles.abstract: Toyota has had a run of bad news this year as concerns linger that management has not kept up with a rapid growth rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Nov. 2 — It might seem odd to suggest that a 70-year-old company is going through growing pains, especially one with $183 billion in annual sales.

articles.headline: Citigroup Chief Is Set to Exit Amid Losses
articles.snippet: Charles O. Prince III has told directors that he would resign in the wake of a $5.9 billion write-down.
articles.abstract: Charles O. Prince III has told directors that he would resign in the wake of a $5.9 billion write-down.
articles.lead_paragraph: The embattled head of Citigroup, the global banking giant, has told directors that he would resign from the bank after an emergency meeting this weekend in the wake of a $5.9 billion write-down and sharp drop in profit, people briefed on the situation said last night.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Maker of Lipitor Digs in to Fight Generic Rival
articles.snippet: Many patients on the cholesterol drug are switching to a cheaper alternative, but Pfizer is not letting its flagship product go down without a fight.
articles.abstract: Many patients on the cholesterol drug are switching to a cheaper alternative, but Pfizer is not letting its flagship product go down without a fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is shaping up to be the biggest shift yet to a generic drug, potentially saving the nation $2 billion a year or more in prescription costs.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Saul and Alex Berenson

articles.headline: Loyal to Kerik, Giuliani Missed Warning Signs
articles.snippet: New evidence suggests Rudolph W. Giuliani overlooked disturbing information as he supported Bernard B. Kerik.
articles.abstract: New evidence suggests Rudolph W. Giuliani overlooked disturbing information as he supported Bernard B. Kerik.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Russ Buettner, Michael Powell and William K. Rashbaum and was written by Mr. Powell.

articles.headline: Senate Democrats Facing a ‘Pay as You Go’ Problem
articles.snippet: Senate Democrats need to find a way to raise at least $50 billion in new taxes, or undermine their most important rule for enforcing budget discipline.
articles.abstract: Senate Democrats need to find a way to raise at least $50 billion in new taxes, or undermine their most important rule for enforcing budget discipline.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 — Senate Democrats face an agonizing choice in the days ahead: find a way to raise at least $50 billion in new taxes, or undermine their most important rule for enforcing budget discipline.

articles.headline: Where Did the Buck Stop at Merrill?
articles.snippet: Analysts are asking to what extent accountability for oversight of financial strategies reached beyond the chief executive’s suite and into the boardroom.
articles.abstract: Analysts are asking to what extent accountability for oversight of financial strategies reached beyond the chief executive’s suite and into the boardroom.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON Oct. 24, Merrill Lynch announced its biggest write-down ever, an $8.4 billion charge that also represents the biggest known loss in Wall Street history. Six days later, its chief executive, E. Stanley O’Neal, retired from the company he had run since 2002.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: New Detainee Rights Weighed in Plans to Close Guantánamo
articles.snippet: Administration officials are considering granting Guantánamo detainees greater rights in an effort to close the detention center.
articles.abstract: Administration officials are considering granting Guantánamo detainees greater rights in an effort to close the detention center.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 — Administration officials are considering granting Guantánamo detainees substantially greater rights as part of an effort to close the detention center and possibly move much of its population to the United States, according to officials involved in the discussions.

articles.headline: Pakistani Sets Emergency Rule, Defying the U.S.
articles.snippet: The move appeared to be an effort by Gen. Pervez Musharraf to reassert power in the face of opposition.
articles.abstract: The move appeared to be an effort by Gen. Pervez Musharraf to reassert power in the face of opposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by David Rohde, Jane Perlez and Salman Masood, and was written by Mr. Rohde.

articles.headline: I, Robot: The Man Behind the Google Phone
articles.snippet: With battle lines being drawn in the smartphone market, Google is placing its bets in the hands of Andy Rubin.
articles.abstract: With battle lines being drawn in the smartphone market, Google is placing its bets in the hands of Andy Rubin.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mountain View, Calif.

articles.headline: A Ray of Pension Sunshine
articles.snippet: Increased scrutiny on the costly effects that middlemen can have on pensions will surely help investors and pension beneficiaries.
articles.abstract: Increased scrutiny on the costly effects that middlemen can have on pensions will surely help investors and pension beneficiaries.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE Securities and Exchange Commission’s investigation into possible conflicts of interest among advisers to pension funds has been going on so long — two years — that it’s practically fallen off the radar screen. But last week, the investigation cropped up again, big time, when Merrill Lynch advised 100 of its pension fund clients in Florida that the S.E.C. has taken issue with its practices as a consultant.

articles.headline: Devices Enforce Silence of Cellphones, Illegally
articles.snippet: A gadget that jams cellular signals has gained popularity as the use of cellphones has invaded more public places.
articles.abstract: A gadget that jams cellular signals has gained popularity as the use of cellphones has invaded more public places.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 — One afternoon in early September, an architect boarded his commuter train and became a cellphone vigilante. He sat down next to a 20-something woman who he said was “blabbing away” into her phone.

articles.headline: Capital Cases Stall as Costs Grow Daunting
articles.snippet: States unwilling to pay the huge costs of defending people charged in capital cases may be unable to hold executions.
articles.abstract: States unwilling to pay the huge costs of defending people charged in capital cases may be unable to hold executions.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Nov. 3 — When Hilton M. Fuller Jr., a semiretired judge of the silver-haired, Southern-gentleman variety, agreed to preside over the trial in a notorious courthouse shooting here, he took a job no one else wanted — the legal community was still in shock over the death of a judge, a court reporter, a sheriff’s deputy and a federal agent.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Brenda Goodman

articles.headline: Fixing Citigroup Will Test Rubin
articles.snippet: Robert E. Rubin, named chairman of Citigroup, will seek to revive the troubled bank, which said it would take an additional $8 billion to $11 billion write-down.
articles.abstract: Robert E. Rubin, named chairman of Citigroup, will seek to revive the troubled bank, which said it would take an additional $8 billion to $11 billion write-down.
articles.lead_paragraph: Throughout a long, public career, Robert E. Rubin spanned the highest reaches of Wall Street and Washington, and succeeded wherever he went.

articles.headline: Pakistan Rounds Up Musharraf’s Political Foes
articles.snippet: Pakistan’s government detained opposition figures and said parliamentary elections could be delayed for as long as a year.
articles.abstract: Pakistan’s government detained opposition figures and said parliamentary elections could be delayed for as long as a year.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 4 — The government of Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani president, making no concessions a day after seizing emergency powers, rounded up leading opposition figures and said Sunday that parliamentary elections could be delayed for as long as a year.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and David Rohde

articles.headline: As Citigroup Chief Totters, CNBC Reporter Is Having a Great Year
articles.snippet: After enduring accusations in the media of questionable interactions with Citigroup, CNBC’s Maria Bartiromo is now in the midst of a turnaround year.
articles.abstract: After enduring accusations in the media of questionable interactions with Citigroup, CNBC’s Maria Bartiromo is now in the midst of a turnaround year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The big story on CNBC all day today will undoubtedly be the fallout from the resignation of Charles O. Prince III as chairman of Citigroup — and Maria Bartiromo, one of the best-known names in business news on television, will surely be among the reporters covering it.

articles.headline: Different Rules When a Rival Is a Woman?
articles.snippet: The question of gender has burst into the foreground of the campaign in the aftermath of a contentious debate.
articles.abstract: The question of gender has burst into the foreground of the campaign in the aftermath of a contentious debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES, Nov. 4 — A critical question in this campaign — how to run against a female presidential candidate, or as one — has burst into the foreground in the aftermath of a Democratic debate last week at which Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was repeatedly challenged by her rivals and the event’s questioners.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Big Executive of the Tiny Screen
articles.snippet: Cyriac Roeding, executive vice president of CBS Mobile, is an unapologetic entrepreneur who isn’t afraid to take a trial-and-error approach to fielding fresh talent.
articles.abstract: Cyriac Roeding, executive vice president of CBS Mobile, is an unapologetic entrepreneur who isn’t afraid to take a trial-and-error approach to fielding fresh talent.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When CBS Mobile introduced the Daily Delivery, a short video for cellphones highlighting fashionable shops in Los Angeles and cool gadgets, it was a disaster.

articles.headline: Trial Near for Shiite Ex-Officials in Sunni Killings
articles.snippet: Two former Iraqi Health Ministry officials, both Shiites, will be tried in the killing of hundreds of Sunnis.
articles.abstract: Two former Iraqi Health Ministry officials, both Shiites, will be tried in the killing of hundreds of Sunnis.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Nov. 3 — An Iraqi judge has ruled that there is enough evidence to try two former Health Ministry officials, both Shiites, in the killing and kidnapping of hundreds of Sunnis, many of them snatched from hospitals by militias, according to American officials who are advising the Iraqi judicial system.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Bankers’ Lesson From Mortgage Mess: Sell, Don’t Hold
articles.snippet: Top executives at two of the world’s largest banks have come under scrutiny for ignoring one of the fundamental principles of the banking business.
articles.abstract: Top executives at two of the world’s largest banks have come under scrutiny for ignoring one of the fundamental principles of the banking business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bankers on Wall Street frequently describe themselves as being in the moving and not the storage business. They make money by trading stocks and bonds, not by owning them.

articles.headline: A Lilly Drug Logs Success and Risks in Heart Trial
articles.snippet: An experimental drug from Eli Lilly reduced heart attacks in patients with heart disease by 24 percent compared with the current standard treatment.
articles.abstract: An experimental drug from Eli Lilly reduced heart attacks in patients with heart disease by 24 percent compared with the current standard treatment.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 4 — An experimental anticlotting drug from Eli Lilly reduced heart attacks in patients with heart disease by 24 percent compared with Plavix, the current standard treatment, according to a report released Sunday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

articles.headline: New Media, New Value, Old Troubles
articles.snippet: If the Hollywood screenwriters go on strike, the typical American household will not run out of content any time soon. But will the audience return after a lengthy strike?
articles.abstract: If the Hollywood screenwriters go on strike, the typical American household will not run out of content any time soon. But will the audience return after a lengthy strike?
articles.lead_paragraph: In the hierarchy of things the American public seems not to care about — the national debt, Paris Hilton’s charitable works, Fred D. Thompson’s campaign for president — the Hollywood screenwriters’ strike probably wins hands down.
